question: What tier are we in now and who does it include?
answer:
• We are working through Tiers 1 and 2.1 until February 1.
  • Tier 1:
    • Medical Staff.
    • Dentists, Dental Hygienists and Dental Assistants.
    • Pharmacists, Pharmacy Techs and Aides.
    • Public Health and Emergency Response Workers.
  • Tier 2.1:
    • Educators.
    • Frontline Essential Workers that are high risk of exposure.
    • Adults 65 years of Age and Older.

question: Are you still taking vaccine appointments at Family Medical?
answer:
• NO. We are NOT scheduling any additional appointments at this time.
  • We have had a large response from those wanting the vaccine.
  • Today we were notified that Idaho received a limited amount of vaccine.
  • This means it limits us to 100 vaccines a week, not the 150 we had requested and anticipated receiving.

question: Does that mean you will be cancelling and rescheduling some of the vaccine appointments already scheduled?
answer:
• Yes – We will have to shift the vaccine schedules around to meet the number of vaccines we will be getting.
  • We want to ask for your patience and understanding if you receive a call asking you to reschedule.
  • Everyone involved, including the health districts, are doing the best they can to organize the vaccine distribution efficiently, especially when parts of the vaccine plan are out of our control.
  • We are also doing our best to communicate our vaccine plans and any changes, as soon as the information becomes available to us.

question: Can I go to other locations and get my vaccine?
answer: • Yes, However, I would call and make sure they have vaccine available and that you are in the categories they are vaccinating.

question: Are there any plans for mass vaccination sites in Washington County?
answer: • With the limited vaccines available, not at this time.

question: Are their plans to set up vaccination sites in Cambridge and Midvale?
I have had COVID-19, do I still need to get the vaccine?
answer:
• According to the CDC – reinfection with COVID-19 is still possible.
  • The vaccine should be considered regardless of whether you already had the COVID-19 infection.

question: Will the COVID-19 vaccination protect me from getting COVID?
answer: • Yes - The COVID-19 vaccination works by teaching your immune system how to recognize and fight the virus that causes COVID-19, and this protects you from getting sick with COVID-19.

question: What type of side effects may occur and will they require me to miss work or have someone care for me?
answer:
• Most people experience mild side affects.
  • Your arm may be sore, red and warm to touch.
  • Others have reported headaches or fever. This is a sign that your immune system is working and building up protection to the disease.

question: Am I still a spreader if I have had COVID and/or if I have had my vaccine?
answer:
• Yes. - It takes several weeks to build up vaccine-induced antibodies and other immune defenses, and both vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna require a booster dose 21 to 28 days after the first dose. So, the full protection offered by the vaccines would take at least a month to develop.
  • And since the vaccines don’t work perfectly, and it’s not known yet to what extent they prevent infection, it’s possible that a vaccinated person might still get the virus and be able to pass it on to others.
  • People will still need to wear masks, socially distance, wash their hands and avoid large gatherings, especially indoors.
  • It will take time to vaccinate everyone. Until that happens and until it’s clear how well the vaccines prevent transmission, safety measures are still needed.

question: Why do I still have to wear a mask after I am vaccinated?
answer: • We can be immune and still be a carrier.

question: How will we know how long our immunity last if we have had COVID-19?
answer:
• At this time, experts do not know how long someone is protected from getting sick again after recovering from COVID-19.
  • The immunity someone gains from having an infection, called natural immunity, varies from person to person. Some early evidence suggests natural immunity may not last very long.

question: With the new virus being more contagious, should I be wearing an N95 mask?
answer:
• The CDC is not recommending N95 masks.
  • N95s are critical supplies that must continue to be reserved for health care workers and other medical first responders, as recommended by CDC.

question: When will there be a vaccine for our kids?
answer:
• Several companies have begun enrolling children as young as age 12 in COVID-19 vaccine clinical trials.
  • Studies including younger children will begin soon.
  • Currently the COVID-19 vaccine is only available to people age 16 and older.
